image.altText: cash lays on a kitchen table beside a cup of tea and a list of bills owing

items.synopsis: Swelling iron ore royalties and GST payments from the Commonwealth are set to hand the WA government a bumper surplus of more than $4 billion for the third straight year.

title.children: Huge surplus and $400 electricity rebates: Here's what to expect from today's WA budget

image.altText: A close-up side-on shot of WA Premier Mark McGowan speaking outside state parliament, with a woman out of focus on his left.

items.synopsis: In a state still flush with cash, the WA premier is facing pressure to help those who need it most. Keane Bourke examines how Mark McGowan could offer cost-of-living relief when he hands down his third budget as treasurer today.

title.children: With a great surplus comes great responsibility, especially during a cost-of-living crisis

image.altText: Raging flames in a bushfire setting.

items.synopsis: Months of smoke aerosols profusely pumping into the atmosphere during the 2019–2020 bushfires likely triggered a chain reaction that influenced the onset and intensity of the La Niña events, a US study has found.

title.children: Black Summer bushfires may have helped trigger rare triple-dip La Niña

image.altText: Fire burns logs and leaves in a forest.

items.synopsis: A forum hears the WA government's approach to fire management is outdated, with concerns about the medical and environmental harm caused by prescribed burning techniques.

title.children: Scientists warn prescribed burning in WA is outdated and damaging to bushland and communities

image.altText: The outside of a large black building with a Bunbury Farmers Market sign and a hello fresh food delivery service box

items.synopsis: HelloFresh sales representatives told customers their kits contained fresh produce from Bunbury Farmers Market.

title.children: HelloFresh apologises to farmers market over false claims

image.altText: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price and Warren Mundine speak at a meeting. Mr Mundine has his arm out gesturing.

items.synopsis: The two campaigns pushing for a No vote to the forthcoming Voice to Parliament referendum merge, in a move that aims to unify their message and strengthen their campaign.

title.children: Key 'No' Voice camps merge to strengthen referendum campaign

image.altText: Treasurer Jim Chalmers holds a copy of the 2023-24 federal budget strategy and outlook book in front of the media

items.synopsis: We now know what the government thinks it will cost to futureproof the NDIS — a whopping $74 billion in savings over the next decade. So why didn't the treasurer cite this impressive number in his budget speech, writes David Speers.

title.children: The whopping $74b budget saving that Chalmers kept quiet

image.altText: A man speaks in parliament wearing a suit with various politicians seated on the green benches behind him

items.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers used his budget speech this week to spruik the government's credentials and programs. But did he keep his facts straight?

title.children: We fact checked Jim Chalmers's budget night speech. Here's what we found

image.altText: a white 4WD travels down a road at night as a small child hangs out the window

items.synopsis: Youth crime has long been a problem in Kununurra, but a recent spate of car thefts and attempted police car rammings has leaders worried about children committing serious offences while out on bail.

title.children: Crisis talks over youth crime in WA town amid concern kids committing serious offences while on bail

image.altText: Josephine Thompson is pictured with her brother eating food at Centrecare's breakfast program for homeless people in Broome.

items.synopsis: With an average wait time of 235 weeks for social housing, rough sleepers and the services supporting them say more needs to be done to support vulnerable people in the tourist town.

title.children: Broome's vulnerable residents fearful for their lives while waiting for social housing

image.altText: A Sydney tram with emergency workers alongside

items.synopsis: Emergency services worked to free the 16-year-old, who had critical injuries, but she died at the scene.

title.children: Teenage girl dies after becoming trapped under light rail tram in Sydney CBD

image.altText: A woman wearing blue scrubs has her arm around an older woman wearing a pink cardigan as they walk across a lush green lawn.

items.synopsis: Older Australians are increasingly opting to receive care at home, rather than in residential aged care, a shift that the federal government projects will save billions of dollars.

title.children: Deep within the budget was a revelation: The way the government views aged care is changing

image.altText: A piece of land with the Australian flag and the Chinese flag next to each other with a big crack separating the two

items.synopsis: Australia's Trade Minister Don Farrell will hold a meeting with his Chinese counterpart in Beijing this week, with hopes it could signal the trade turmoil between China and Australia will soon be over.

title.children: Trade Minister Don Farrell to visit China in push to end trade bans on barley, meat and wine

image.altText: Man in diving gear touching the mouth of a large whale shark underwater.

items.synopsis: Making a natural history documentary is a test of patience and endurance, and Tim Winton had finally run out of both. He was trying to capture the wild beauty of his beloved Ningaloo Reef but Mother Nature wouldn't play ball.

title.children: Tim Winton picked parasites off whale shark's mouth, but that's not what 'terrified' him

image.altText: An LNG tanker

items.synopsis: Energy company Eni has quietly revived plans to develop a gas field in the Timor Sea which contains some of the most carbon-intensive gas in Australia, "far more than any other gas field that is being developed".

title.children: Italian company moves ahead with 'carbon bomb' gas field in Timor Sea

image.altText: A middle-aged woman looks at the camera, standing in front of a sandstone wall

items.synopsis: A group of people whose families profited from slavery is trying to make amends for past wrongs.

title.children: Laura is an 'heir of slavery'. Here's what she's doing to remedy her family's brutal legacy

image.altText: Horses trek through dirt.

items.synopsis: Right to Information documents show a complaint about "race fixing" against Tasmania's leading harness racing stable was received by the Office of Racing Integrity in 2016, seven years before an extensive ABC investigation.

title.children: Racing integrity office had complaint of alleged 'race fixing' against Ben Yole dating back to 2016

image.altText: Brittany Higgins speaks at a podium.

items.synopsis: John Korn, who represented Bruce Lehrmann, recalls his "somewhat inappropriate" advice to the ACT's top prosecutor to prevent a speech at the National Press Club about sexual assault.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann's lawyer demanded chief prosecutor try to stop Brittany Higgins speech

image.altText: a homemade missing poster with a picture of a woman printed on white paper and thumbtacked to a fence

items.synopsis: Police have suspended their search at an Ipswich dump for missing Toowong woman Lesley Trotter, whose body is believed to have been put in a wheelie bin outside her home last month.

title.children: Police suspend search of landfill site for missing woman Lesley Trotter's body

image.altText: A back view of people wearing orange and yellow Search Crew vests walking across a bridge.

items.synopsis: Fourteen-year-old Shyanne-Lee Tatnell has not been seen or heard from since April 30. Now community members are getting involved in the search to find her.

title.children: Community search underway for missing Launceston teen Shyanne-Lee after 10 days without a trace

image.altText: An old image of Heather Winchester sitting on the couch holding her baby grandson.

items.synopsis: The Newcastle doctor has told an inquest that the Jehovah's Witness patient was lucid and clear while refusing a potentially life-saving blood transfusion.

title.children: Jehovah's Witness woman preferred to die than accept blood transfusion, distressed doctor tells inquest

image.altText: DUPLICATE vape

items.synopsis: A Brisbane convenience store has been caught with 45,000 vapes and ordered to pay $88,000 for possessing and selling vapes containing nicotine.

title.children: Principal tips off investigators about sale of vapes to school children, resulting in conviction

image.altText: Jess and Jackie Morecroft stand in the driveway of their home.

items.synopsis: After a five-year court battle, the Morecrofts lost their Gold Coast family home. Now they're facing legal costs that could financially ruin them.

title.children: Couple told they never owned house they paid for 'at wits' end' over order to pay legal costs

image.altText: Prince Harry with a beard and furrowed brow wearing a suit and tie

items.synopsis: A British tabloid newspaper apologises to Prince Harry for unlawfully seeking information about him at the start of the royal's lawsuit against its publisher over alleged phone hacking, in which he is due to give evidence himself.

title.children: 'Blatantly unlawful': British tabloid apologises to Prince Harry

image.altText: Photo of an industrial storage tank with a no smoking sign in front.

items.synopsis: Economists and energy experts say the government is short-changing Australians with planned changes to the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax that will only raise an additional $2.4 billion over five years.

title.children: Smokers will see a bigger tax increase than multinational gas producers. Is it fair?

image.altText: An ASX board with ASX in focus and stock prices out of focus.

items.synopsis: Local shares are trading lower after overnight news that US inflation is cooling but still too high. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX slips after mixed day on Wall Street as inflation cools

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ASX 200: -0.2% to 7,236 points All Ordinaries: -0.2% to 7,433 points Australian dollar: -0.1% 67.70 US cents Dow Jones: -0.09% to 33,531 points S & P 500: +0.4% to 4,137 points Nasdaq: +1% to 12,306 points FTSE: -0.3% to 7,741points EuroStoxx: -0.4% to 463 points Spot gold: +0.1% to $US2,039/ounce Brent crude: +0.2% $US76.63 /barrel Iron ore: $US103.35/tonne Bitcoin: -0.08% at $US27,556
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Market snapshot 12:00pm AEST

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The jobs market appears to be moderating, but listings on Seek are still much higher than before the COVID pandemic hit. Job ads on listings website Seek fell 1.4 per cent in April. SEEK job ads are now 21 per cent below their May 2022 peak, but still remain 35 per cent above pre-pandemic levels. NAB economist Taylor Nugent notes while job ads fell 20.6 per cent from their May 2022 peak to December, over the past four months have fallen just 0.5 per cent. "The decline in job ads from May last year was a key indicator of some easing in exceptionally tight labour market conditions. This was especially evident in some pockets of the labour market, notably hospitality and tourism," Mr Nugent notes. Mr Nugent said the labour market overall remains tight with the unemployment rate still at 3.5 per cent, broadly where it has been since the middle of 2022. "Strong labour demand is absorbing the strong lift in population growth without a lift in the unemployment rate." "Applications per Job Ad, released with a 1-month lag, continue to increase from the lows of May 2022, and are similar to 2018 levels, which also suggests some of the more acute challenges finding labour may be receding." Despite the overall decline, 11 of 28 industries recorded an increase in ads in the month. The largest increase was recorded in Education and Training. "This high-employing industry has a tailwind from the rapid rebound in international students and is the only industry to see advertising above the earlier May 2022 peak. Education and Training Ads are now at a new high, 3% higher than in May 2022. The number of international students has rebounded sharply, rising 246k, or 73%, in the year to Q1 2023," Mr Nugent notes. "In contrast, Hospitality & Tourism Ads, another high-employing industry, was among the largest decliners in the month with advertising falling 5.7%," he notes. Official Bureau of Statistics unemployment data comes out on Thursday. NAB forecasts the unemployment rate to move higher toward 4 per cent by the end of 2023.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Jobs market moderating, but listings still 35pc higher than before COVID

children.content: The jobs market appears to be moderating, but listings on Seek are still much higher than before the COVID pandemic hit.
Job ads on listings website Seek fell 1.4 per cent in April.
SEEK job ads are now 21 per cent below their May 2022 peak, but still remain 35 per cent above pre-pandemic levels.
notes while job ads fell 20.6 per cent from their May 2022 peak to December, over the past four months have fallen just 0.5 per cent.

"The decline in job ads from May last year was a key indicator of some easing in exceptionally tight labour market conditions. This was especially evident in some pockets of the labour market, notably hospitality and tourism," Mr Nugent notes.
Mr Nugent said the labour market overall remains tight with the unemployment rate still at 3.5 per cent, broadly where it has been since the middle of 2022.
"Strong labour demand is absorbing the strong lift in population growth without a lift in the unemployment rate."

"Applications per Job Ad, released with a 1-month lag, continue to increase from the lows of May 2022, and are similar to 2018 levels, which also suggests some of the more acute challenges finding labour may be receding."
Despite the overall decline, 11 of 28 industries recorded an increase in ads in the month.
The largest increase was recorded in Education and Training.

"This high-employing industry has a tailwind from the rapid rebound in international students and is the only industry to see advertising above the earlier May 2022 peak. Education and Training Ads are now at a new high, 3% higher than in May 2022. The number of international students has rebounded sharply, rising 246k, or 73%, in the year to Q1 2023,"
Tourism Ads, another high-employing industry, was among the largest decliners in the month with advertising falling 5.7%," he notes.
Official Bureau of Statistics unemployment data comes out on Thursday.
NAB forecasts the unemployment rate to move higher toward 4 per cent by the end of 2023.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's just clocked over to the afternoon trading session. The ASX 200 has fallen by a quarter of a per cent. Utilities, miners and industrials are weighing on the benchmark index. Allkem's merger and company results are dominating the gains and declines.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Industrials, miners drag on the ASX 200

children.content: It's just clocked over to the afternoon trading session.
The ASX 200 has fallen by a quarter of a per cent.
Utilities, miners and industrials are weighing on the benchmark index.
Allkem's merger and company results are dominating the gains and declines.

image.altText: A view from a helicopter shows charred grounds and a large plume of smoke coming from a forested area.

items.synopsis: The death toll has risen to 21 in a series of fires raging in Russia's Urals region, some resulting from suspected arson, while medical officials warn the tally is likely to increase, Russian state news agency TASS reports.

title.children: Death toll from wildfires in Russia's Urals hits 21, authorities suspect arson

image.altText: A Ukrainian serviceman waves from a tank, as Russia's attack on Ukraine continues.

items.synopsis: A Ukrainian military unit says it has routed a Russian infantry brigade from frontline territory near Bakhmut, confirming an account by the head of Russia's Wagner Group that the Russian forces have fled.

title.children: 'Retreated': Ukraine and Wagner confirm Russian troops failing in Bakhmut

image.altText: A black and white re-creation of a face of an unknown woman found in The Netherlands.

items.synopsis: The unsolved murders of 22 women are the subject of an appeal for information launched on by global police agency Interpol, together with Belgian, German and Dutch police.

title.children: European police hope to identify 22 unknown women in a bid to solve cold case murders

image.altText: A brunette woman in a white cardigan holding a baby.

items.synopsis: Despite a recognised need for increased childcare capacity, two proposed centres have been knocked back in Wagga Wagga over the past 15 months as neighbouring residents raise objections.

title.children: Holli put her son's name on a childcare waitlist when he was in utero. She's still waiting

image.altText: A view of rockets being fired at night.

items.synopsis: Palestinian militants fire more than 300 rockets into Israel as Israel presses ahead with a series of deadly air strikes on the Gaza strip.

title.children: UN calls for calm as Gaza conflict flares again

image.altText: A man and woman stand in front of a tree and look sternly at the camera

items.synopsis: High valuations are great news for people wanting to sell, but those holding onto it will feel the consequences, says a peak rural lobby group after the Queensland valuer-general upped the monetary worth of some rural blocks.

title.children: Unhappy with his property's value skyrocketing, Rob's decided to fight the hike

image.altText: A white labradoodle dog stands proudly next to his certificate

items.synopsis: A rural teacher says the effort that has gone into training her labradoodle to be a therapy dog is worth it as soon as she sees how students and staff interact with him.

title.children: When Alby the labradoodle starts his day as a school therapy dog, he knows he's got a 'job to do'

image.altText: An Australian progressive metal group pose for the camera in a corridor backstage at the venue for the Eurovision Song Contest.

items.synopsis: Perth progressive metal band Voyager are finally achieving their dream to make Eurovision history, as the first group to represent Australia — they talk to ABC about the long road to the Contest, the songs that didn't quite make it, their Spinal Tap moment in Amsterdam, and more.

title.children: From Runaway to Dreamer to Promise, how Voyager finally made it to Eurovision
